node.title: Dunedin council moves in on protesters occupying Octagon
node.description: The Dunedin City Council wants the anti-mandate protesters camped out in the city's Octagon to leave, saying their cause has now run its course.

node.title: NZ woolgrowers among sectors hit by China's Covid-19 restrictions
node.description: A resurgence of Covid-19 within China is causing headaches for some primary sector exporters, with lockdown measures disrupting economic activity and slowing down distribution networks.

node.title: Two men allegedly impersonated federal agents to get access to Secret Service
node.description: The two allegedly used fake credentials to get closer to members of federal law enforcement agencies, including Secret Service agents assigned to the first lady.

node.title: Healthy drinks in schools plan goes out for consultation
node.description: Water, milk and milk alternatives: the government is seeking feedback on a plan to ban all other drinks from primary schools to keep children healthy.

node.title: Mortgage applications fall as economic uncertainty bites
node.description: With borrowers feeling the pinch, consumer credit demand is down 9 percent in the year to March, and mortgage applications fell 19 percent, data from Centrix shows.

node.title: Silence over why mall attacker's request to leave NZ ignored
node.description: Government agencies which battled to detain and deport the LynnMall attacker Ahamed Samsudeen are remaining silent on why they did not agree to his request to lose New Zealand residence.

node.title: Kaikōura businesses wait for tourists to return: 'We know we'll get there'
node.description: Kaikōura businesses are remaining optimistic about the future despite the return of tourists predicted to still be months away.

node.title: Tiwai Point plans to shift landfill higher up into a lined pit on the site
node.description: The Tiwai Point aluminium smelter aims to relocate its massive landfill to higher ground under a preliminary closure plan released today.

node.title: Texas teacher resigns after student burned during science experiment
node.description: Authorities said a teacher put hand sanitizer in a student's hands and lit the flammable solution on fire.

node.title: Bloomfield's resignation: 'He felt the pain, he felt the pressure along with the rest of us'
node.description: Health workers are describing the departing Director-General of Health as having been vital in getting the country through the pandemic. Audio

node.title: DHS chief denies double standard at the southern border for Ukrainian refugees
node.description: Ukrainian refugees have been an exception to the Trump-era policy that led to the quick deportations of hundreds of thousands of migrants from Central America during the COVID-19 pandemic.

node.title: School superintendent arrested for allegedly lying about sending threats to police chief candidate
node.description: Lynn Clark allegedly sent nearly 100 threatening messages to the police chief candidate, forcing them to withdraw and delaying the election.

node.title: GOP probe of Hunter Biden's business dealings expands to James Biden
node.description: GOP Senator Chuck Grassley tells CBS News that his concerns are related to newly obtained banking records.

node.title: Business more trusted than government, media in NZ - survey
node.description: Business as a sector is more trusted than any other New Zealand institution according to a global survey, with nearly two thirds of people trusting employers to do what is right.

node.title: Widespread problems with Clean Car Discount scheme rebates and fees - MTA
node.description: Car dealers are being warned the Clean Car Discount system is in some cases calculating fees and rebates wrongly. Audio

node.title: Underwhelming uptake for Kāinga Ora First Home scheme
node.description: Kāinga Ora is positive about its First Home Partner scheme, despite taking more than four months for a single property to be settled.

node.title: Gun clubs worry Arms Act changes will misfire for hobby shooters
node.description: Gun clubs warn some will fold as a result of regulations arising from the Christchurch terror attacks, forcing hunters and shooters to blaze away in the back blocks instead of ranges.

node.title: More people biking in Christchurch than in any other New Zealand city
node.description: More Christchurch locals are getting on their bikes with one cycling advocate saying its boost in popularity is down to investment in cycleways after the 2011 earthquakes.

node.title: National Geographic photo prints for sale, with proceeds going to Ukraine relief
node.description: The women-owned nonprofit Vital Impacts is partnering with National Geographic photographers to raise money for Direct Relief.

node.title: IRD says high income earners may be trying to avoid new tax bracket
node.description: The tax department thinks some high income earners may be trying to avoid the new top tax bracket, with officials concerned that people are shifting money around to avoid paying.

node.title: "Enormous economic repercussions" from Russian invasion, Yellen says
node.description: The prices of fuel and food are rising, and Deutsche Bank is projecting a recession in the U.S.

node.title: Miami Bitcoin 2022 expo draws crypto-crazed to growing tech hub
node.description: Thousands of crypto enthusiasts are gathering in Miami, now tied with Los Angeles in funding raised by blockchain startups.

node.title: Pentagon training a small number of Ukrainians in the U.S. on new weapons
node.description: The Pentagon said Wednesday the U.S. has given some training to Ukrainians who were in the U.S. already.

node.title: People with lingering Covid-19 symptoms struggling with brain fog, returning to work
node.description: Post-viral brain fog is causing forgetfulness, fuzziness, and frustration for New Zealanders trying to return to work after Covid-19.

node.title: IRD says high income earners likely trying to avoid new tax bracket
node.description: The tax department thinks some high income earners may be trying to avoid the new top tax bracket, with officials concerned that people are shifting money around to avoid paying.

node.title: 'We have no idea of the real numbers' - Memo highlights fear RAT tests unrecorded
node.description: A leading epidemiologist says we have no idea how many community cases of Covid-19 there are in New Zealand because so many people aren't recording their rapid antigen test results.

node.title: FDA warns of raw oysters potentially contaminated with norovirus
node.description: Health officials are working to curtail outbreak that has sickened at least 91 people in 13 states and 279 Canadians.

node.title: Mortgage rates top 5% — and loan applications take a hit
node.description: The average 30-year home loan rate hasn't topped 5% in more than a decade, according to Freddie Mac data.

node.title: Russian and Belarusian athletes banned from 2022 Boston Marathon
node.description: The BAA announced that anyone currently residing in either Russia or Belarus will not be able to compete in the Boston Marathon or BAA 5K.

node.title: Nothing off table with future sanctions against Russia - US official
node.description: The US State Department's John Armstrong says after a career working in the region it is truly painful to see what has happened to Ukraine. He told Checkpoint it will not be a short conflict. Audio
